Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Hypoxia-induced trade-offs on zooplankton vertical distribution and community structure in freshwaters
Award.AbstractNarration:
The overarching goal of this research project is to determine how altered dissolved oxygen (DO) concentrations in the bottom waters of lakes and reservoirs affect zooplankton behavior, abundances, and species composition, and how these changes may have consequences for water quality and food webs. Zooplankton play a critical role in freshwater ecosystems; they feed on phytoplankton, the base of the food web, and are in turn consumed by fish. Consequently, changes in zooplankton populations have the potential to drastically alter water quality and food webs. Zooplankton in freshwater ecosystems around the world exhibit diel vertical migration, in which they migrate to the bottom waters of a lake or reservoir during the day to escape visual predation by fish and damaging ultraviolet (UV) radiation. At night, many zooplankton migrate to the water's surface to feed on phytoplankton when the risk of predation and UV exposure is lower. However, human activities are resulting in decreased DO concentrations in the bottom waters of waterbodies globally. As a result of decreased DO, zooplankton may remain in the surface waters during the day and no longer vertically migrate, resulting in decreased abundance and changes in the species composition. This research will be conducted in partnership with a local water utility, and all data and results will be shared with managers to inform their water quality decisions. The project will involve training of at least two undergraduate researchers in freshwater science laboratory and field methods in an interdisciplinary setting. In addition, results from this research will provide the basis for creating interactive and hands-on educational activities for school children at a nature center.

This project will integrate a unique whole-ecosystem manipulation of bottom water (hypolimnetic) DO concentrations, a cross-ecosystem survey of reservoirs on a hypolimnetic DO gradient, high-frequency sonar to observe the diel vertical distribution of zooplankton, and experimental analyses of zooplankton functional traits to examine how changes in DO concentrations alter zooplankton species composition, abundance, and behavior. Biweekly summer field surveys will be conducted across five reservoirs that exhibit a range of hypolimnetic DO concentrations. One of the reservoirs has a hypolimnetic oxygenation system that will be experimentally turned on and off (thereby controlling DO concentrations at the whole-ecosystem scale) to directly assess the effects of DO on zooplankton populations. Multiple diel sampling campaigns will also be conducted that use sonar acoustic technology to observe the vertical distribution of zooplankton in the water column. Taken together, these integrated research approaches will mechanistically determine the effects of changing DO concentrations on zooplankton communities and resulting implications for water quality in lakes and reservoirs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Species interactions, migration patterns, and the composition of many ecological communities have been altered globally because of humans. In freshwater lakes and reservoirs, warmer water temperatures and increased nutrient pollution have resulted in low oxygen concentrations (hypoxia) in the bottom waters (hypolimnion) of many waterbodies. Hypoxia can affect organisms living in these environments that need oxygen to survive, which can disrupt the water quality and function of the ecosystem. Zooplankton, or animal plankton, are one group of organisms affected by hypoxia that play an important role in aquatic ecosystems. Zooplankton prey on phytoplankton (at the base of the food chain) and are consumed by fish; therefore, any changes to zooplankton populations can affect both water quality and fisheries. 

Zooplankton in lakes and reservoirs around the world exhibit diel vertical migration, in which the majority of the population resides in the hypolimnion during the daytime to escape predation from fish and damage from ultraviolet (UV) radiation. At night, many zooplankton ascend to the surface waters to feed on phytoplankton, when there is decreased risk of predation and radiation. However, hypoxia may create a trade-off for zooplankton during the daytime, in which they trade oxic stress in the hypolimnion for increased predation risk or damage from UV radiation in the surface waters. To better understand how hypoxia affects zooplankton communities, zooplankton and other environmental data were sampled over 24-hour periods to capture the transition between day and nighttime dynamics in four reservoirs in southwestern Virginia. These same reservoirs were sampled fortnightly during the daytime over multiple years to complement the diel sampling. 

Data from this project indicate that hypolimnetic hypoxia affects the migration patterns of zooplankton. A key finding of this research is that zooplankton largely do not migrate vertically when the hypolimnion becomes hypoxic, though they will exhibit diel vertical migration when there is oxygen in the hypolimnion. Furthermore, zooplankton density and biomass were lower in seasonally hypoxic reservoirs compared to seasonally oxic reservoirs, despite there being more phytoplankton food for zooplankton in the hypoxic reservoirs. Consequently, as lakes and reservoirs experience an increased extent and duration of hypoxia in the future, this work provides critical information on how altered migration, biomass, and variability of zooplankton communities affect freshwater ecosystem functioning.

This project provided significant training for five undergraduate students and five graduate students, and has supported four peer-reviewed papers to date, with an additional manuscript in revision and one in preparation. The research team presented seven presentations at scientific conferences and communicated the study’s results with local water utilities throughout the duration of the project to improve water quality management and decision-making. In addition, the research team conducted substantial outreach with local communities in southwest Virginia, including developing an educational display at a nature center and an educational pamphlet on the results of the project for the public.
